subdomains.name: First-Order ODEs
subdomains.description: Ordinary differential equations involving only the first derivative. The gateway to modeling change.
subdomains.flavor: The First Current — where motion begins and every changing thing finds its voice.

topics.name: Separable Equations
topics.description: ODEs where variables can be isolated on opposite sides. Solved by direct integration after separation.
topics.flavor: Pull the variables apart and let each side tell its own story.

topics.name: Linear First-Order
topics.description: Equations of the form y' + P(x)y = Q(x). Solved using integrating factors.
topics.flavor: A single multiplying trick transforms the unsolvable into the obvious.

topics.name: Exact Equations
topics.description: Equations M dx + N dy = 0 where a potential function exists. Exactness tested by matching partial derivatives.
topics.flavor: Hidden beneath the equation lies a surface — find it, and the solution is a contour line.

topics.name: Existence & Uniqueness
topics.description: The Picard-Lindelof theorem guarantees when solutions exist and are unique. Lipschitz continuity is the key condition.
topics.flavor: Before you solve, ask: does an answer even exist, and is it the only one?

topics.name: Applications (Growth/Decay)
topics.description: Modeling exponential growth, radioactive decay, Newton's cooling, and mixing problems with first-order ODEs.
topics.flavor: The language of change written into every living and dying thing.

subdomains.name: Higher-Order ODEs
subdomains.description: Differential equations involving second derivatives and beyond. The mathematics of oscillation, resonance, and mechanical systems.
subdomains.flavor: The Harmonic Spire — where springs oscillate and bridges sway to the rhythm of higher derivatives.

topics.name: Second-Order Linear
topics.description: Equations of the form y'' + p(x)y' + q(x)y = g(x). The Wronskian determines linear independence of solutions.
topics.flavor: Two independent solutions span a universe of possibilities.

topics.name: Constant Coefficients
topics.description: Linear ODEs with constant coefficients solved via the characteristic equation. Real, repeated, and complex roots each yield distinct solution forms.
topics.flavor: An algebraic equation unlocks the differential one — polynomials and derivatives, secretly the same.

topics.name: Undetermined Coefficients
topics.description: Guessing the form of a particular solution for nonhomogeneous equations. Works when the forcing function is a polynomial, exponential, or sinusoid.
topics.flavor: Guess wisely, and the universe fills in the blanks.

topics.name: Variation of Parameters
topics.description: A general method for finding particular solutions by allowing constants in the homogeneous solution to vary. Works for any forcing function.
topics.flavor: Let the constants dance, and they will find the particular answer you seek.

topics.name: Series Solutions
topics.description: Representing solutions as power series around ordinary and singular points. Frobenius method for regular singular points.
topics.flavor: When closed forms fail, infinite sums carry the truth one coefficient at a time.

subdomains.name: Systems of ODEs
subdomains.description: Multiple coupled differential equations solved simultaneously. The bridge between single equations and the complexity of interacting dynamics.
subdomains.flavor: The Constellation Web — where equations intertwine and futures depend on every neighbor.

topics.name: Linear Systems
topics.description: Systems of the form x' = Ax solved using eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the coefficient matrix.
topics.flavor: Matrices breathe life into vectors, sending them spiraling through state space.

topics.name: Phase Portraits
topics.description: Visualizing solution trajectories in the phase plane. Nodes, spirals, saddles, and centers reveal qualitative behavior.
topics.flavor: Forget the formula — draw the flow and see where the universe drifts.

topics.name: Stability Analysis
topics.description: Classifying equilibrium points as stable, unstable, or asymptotically stable. Eigenvalue signs determine the fate of nearby trajectories.
topics.flavor: Will the system settle, or will it fly apart? The eigenvalues know.

topics.name: Nonlinear Systems
topics.description: Linearization near equilibria via the Jacobian matrix. The Hartman-Grobman theorem connects local behavior to the linearized system.
topics.flavor: Beyond the straight lines, the true shape of nature emerges — curved, tangled, alive.

topics.name: Chaos Theory
topics.description: Sensitive dependence on initial conditions in deterministic systems. Strange attractors, Lyapunov exponents, and the butterfly effect.
topics.flavor: Deterministic yet unpredictable — a butterfly flaps its wings and a storm is born.

subdomains.name: Partial Differential Equations
subdomains.description: Equations involving partial derivatives with respect to multiple independent variables. The language of heat, waves, and fields.
subdomains.flavor: The Nebula of Fields — where functions stretch across space and time simultaneously.

topics.name: Heat Equation
topics.description: The parabolic PDE u_t = k u_xx modeling diffusion and heat conduction. Solutions smooth out initial discontinuities over time.
topics.flavor: Heat flows from hot to cold, and the equation knows exactly how fast.

topics.name: Wave Equation
topics.description: The hyperbolic PDE u_tt = c^2 u_xx describing vibrating strings, sound, and electromagnetic waves. D'Alembert's solution reveals traveling waves.
topics.flavor: Every vibration, every ripple, every note of music — all solutions to one equation.

topics.name: Laplace Equation
topics.description: The elliptic PDE nabla^2 u = 0 describing steady-state potentials. Solutions satisfy the maximum principle and are infinitely smooth.
topics.flavor: The quiet equilibrium — where nothing changes and every point is the average of its neighbors.

topics.name: Separation of Variables
topics.description: Reducing a PDE to a system of ODEs by assuming the solution is a product of single-variable functions. The cornerstone technique for classical PDEs.
topics.flavor: Assume the solution splits, and suddenly the impossible becomes a set of familiar problems.

topics.name: Fourier Series
topics.description: Representing periodic functions as infinite sums of sines and cosines. Essential for expressing initial and boundary conditions in PDE solutions.
topics.flavor: Any shape, any signal — decomposed into an orchestra of pure tones.

subdomains.name: Numerical Methods
subdomains.description: Approximate solutions to differential equations using computation. When analytic methods fail, algorithms carry on.
subdomains.flavor: The Computational Forge — where machines step through time, one tiny increment at a time.

topics.name: Euler's Method
topics.description: The simplest numerical ODE solver: step forward using the tangent line. First-order accurate but foundational for understanding all methods.
topics.flavor: Follow the slope, take a step, look again — the simplest dance with the infinite.

topics.name: Runge-Kutta Methods
topics.description: Higher-order numerical methods that sample the slope at multiple points per step. RK4 is the workhorse of scientific computing.
topics.flavor: Four glances at the slope, and the next step becomes almost perfect.

topics.name: Finite Differences
topics.description: Approximating derivatives by differences on a discrete grid. Transforms PDEs into systems of algebraic equations.
topics.flavor: Replace the smooth with the discrete, and the continuous world yields to computation.

topics.name: Finite Elements
topics.description: Dividing the domain into elements and approximating solutions with piecewise basis functions. The variational approach to PDEs.
topics.flavor: Break space into pieces, solve each one, and stitch together the truth.

topics.name: Stability of Methods
topics.description: Analyzing when numerical methods produce bounded, accurate solutions. CFL conditions and A-stability govern which methods work for which problems.
topics.flavor: A method that grows when it should shrink is worse than no method at all.
